title: 109_hr6274
content: The "Unemployment Tax Equity Act of 2006" establishes a demonstration program for state administration of unemployment compensation programs under the Internal Revenue Code. The Secretary of Labor will establish a demonstration program transferring responsibility for state unemployment compensation laws to participating states. The program is limited to 5 states, and governors can apply to participate. The application to the Secretary of Labor for the demonstration project must include a description of the project, goals, expected outcomes, and how it will help meet the program's purposes. The demonstration program application must include assurances for proper funding, impact evaluation plans, and submission of required reports to the Secretary of Labor. The Secretary of Labor will provide notice to each State regarding the purposes, application requirements, and due date for applications for the demonstration program. Approval or denial of applications will be publicly announced within 30 days. The demonstration project will be in effect for a specified period. A demonstration project under an agreement with the Secretary of Labor lasts 5 years, starting after January 1, 2008, and ending before January 1, 2014. The Secretary can terminate the agreement if the State fails to comply, or the State can terminate with 30 days notice. The agreement with the Secretary of Labor can be terminated if the State fails to comply. Section 3302 will be adjusted for states with demonstration projects, and states participating in such projects will be ineligible for grants under section 302 of the Social Security Act. The table of sections for chapter 23 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new item relating to section 3311, established in a demonstration project. Sec. 3311 establishes a demonstration program for State administration of unemployment compensation program.
